text: headteacher say they might not be able
to reopen primary schools in england in
just three weeks time in line with the
Prime Minister's ambition schools are
expected to limit class sizes to 15
children to stagger breaks and to accept
that strict social distancing will not
always be possible our education
correspondent Alain Dunkley has been
visiting one school in butl this is all
st. primary butell in liverpool teachers
are having a staff meeting to prepare
for the school reopening in just over a
few weeks a hundred and sixty-eight
children could be back in the classrooms
you know now how do we control a head
teacher mrs. Halloran will now have to
ensure that teachers and pupils will be
safe children at this age do not
understand social distancing I'd be very
surprised if any of them did we would
really struggle with I would say five
children in this space the government is
outlined in its guidance how schools can
manage the risk of spreading coronavirus
hygiene will be a priority schools will
need to be stocked with hand sanitizer
children will frequently need to wash
their hands and teachers will be
constantly cleaning the surfaces where
children learn and play a lot of the
things that we do in alias' are
practical resource based activities so
the children touch everything making
sure that we are also cleaners and we're
also toilet supervisors is going to be
very difficult as well as trying to make
sure the curriculum is taught as well as
it can be the Department for Education
has highlighted a number of ways to
minimise contact between children this
is our canteen as you can see a confined
space so staggering inches would present
us with a great challenge it would take
up the best part of the day to be honest
the government says the decision to send
children back to school is based on
scientific advice and safety is a
priority
butl is in one of the most deprived
areas in England and there is concern
the longer schools are closed the wider
the attainment gap between poorer
children and their more affluent peers
the gains that we've made over the last
10 years in narrowing the socio-economic
gap for attainment could be as much as
first do two coronavirus so catching up
is going to be fundamental particularly
for disadvantaged young people these are
testing times in less than three weeks
the government wants children to return
to classes that in my bones I cannot
feel assured is safe
the corona virus pandemic is one of the
biggest challenges that schools have
ever faced
Elaine Dunkley BBC news in Liverpool
recovery for those who have suffered the
worst effects of corona virus is a
prolonged process both physically and
mentally
men are more than twice as likely to
need intensive care than women and
around half of all those who go into
intensive care survive our medical
correspondent Fergus Walsh has been to
University College Hospital in London to
meet some patients at the start of their
rehabilitation slowly delicately
patients almost broken by coronavirus
are being restored Jake who has a heart
condition and diabetes spent three weeks
on a ventilator it was touch and go
whether he'd survived and my chances
we're I think very very low he's still
so weak getting him into a chair is far
from easy
but it's an essential part of his
rehabilitation at University College
Hospital in central London Jake still
has a tracheostomy an opening in his
windpipe which used to be attached to a
ventilator my understanding is the
povery works in very small steps
psychologically
has it been difficult no that I know
does I go back to my family go back to
work go back to the normal routine
I mean to say collage eclis Jake who's
55 hasn't seen his wife Natasha and 17
year old daughter Emily for over a month
except via video physios occupational
and speech therapists dietitians health
psychologists there's a huge team
involved in rehabilitation weakness and
then there's the cognitive impact as
well so the delirium that comes from
being an intensive care unit and the
confusion that comes with being asleep
for many days and waking up to the
reality of all of this and so it's huge
Eddie is struggling with the impact of
kovat 19 on mind as well as body
he's just emerged from intensive care
after a month on a ventilator six years
old and I felt nearness to death
they scored on us as well as physical
therapy he will need psychological
support hallucination wise so many
terrible things that you think are real
even even when you wake up you think
they were real you lived through them do
you mind telling me what sort of things
you were you were imagining I'm good
a little bit of plot where dad was
buried and I could see it the grave
ready there for me to go in there i sir
come come you have to come in there is
ready for you simply surviving intensive
care after this disease is quite an
achievement but the legacy of
coronavirus will be felt by many
patients like Jake far into the future
Fergus Walsh BBC news physical and
mental burden of recovering from the
effects of coronavirus that was Fergus
Walsh reporting there
